pages.text: Pravitoceras sigmoidale comes from the Late Cretaceous, with fossils found in formations across Japan. It is a small nostoceratiid, growing up to 30 cm in size. Despite hailing from a family know for its weird, wacking and mathematical coiling, Pravitoceras is considered to be a relatively normal member, with the only oddity being that after some times of growth, it will bend back round, creating a saxaphone-like shape to its shell. Due to this, it didn't experience
the same amount of drag as seen in its relatives, and also experienced little to no rocking when moving, meaning that it was an relatively fast moving ammonite.
